Award.AwardTitle: Development and Testing of Pressure Gradient Sensors to Improve Shallow Seafloor Seismic Observations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PIs request funding to develop and test on current shielded OBSs orthogonal pairs of horizontal pressure gradient (OPG) sensors. These sensors will be based on the sensor technology originally developed by one of us (Webb) for the differential pressure gauge (DPG) systems currently used on the majority of the US OBS fleet. Theory suggests that these pressure gradient observations should be proportional to the wave deformation loading noise and thus can be used to predict and remove the wave loading noise from the horizontal components. Combining data from a current shielded OBS with data from APG and OPGs sensors may enable broadband seismic observations on the shallow seafloor with noise levels comparable to many land sites greatly improving OBS data for studying the Earth. This project should greatly enhance the capabilities of ocean bottom seismometers deployed in shallow water for studying the seismicity and structure of continental margins crucial to understanding the Earth and the Earth?s seismic hazard.

Broader Impacts:

This instrument development will be a tremendous asset for future relatively shallow water deployments of broadband instruments as it will improve the quality of the data significantly and will make the horizontal component data really useable for a wide range of structural studies. A significant reduction of noise due to waves would benefit a host of OBS programs planned or anticipated in Cascadia, Alaska, New Zealand and elsewhere. Because all of these regions are potential sites of great earthquakes and tsunamis, there are also high societal benefits in improved OBS data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Seismometers provide data to determine the location and size of earthquakes and are used to determine structure and features within the Earth. These data are critical to understanding earthquake, tsunami and volcanic hazards and to understanding geological structures important to resources such as oil, gas and minerals. Some 70% of the Earth?s surface lies beneath the oceans so large fleets of specially built ocean bottom seismometer systems have been constructed and are routinely deployed for long intervals on the seafloor. However the seafloor is a difficult place for seismology as ocean floor currents and ocean wave signals disturb the seismic sensors needed to record the often very tiny ground motions caused by distant earthquakes.  Noise levels for seismic sensors on the seafloor are often millions or tens of millions times noisier (more energetic) on the seafloor compared to quiet land sites obscuring many of the earthquake signals that scientists are trying to detect. 

The project continued the development of better methods to reduce noise levels for seismic sensors deployed on the shallow seafloor where noise levels are the highest because of ocean waves. Observations in shallow water (<300m) are critical to understanding seismic hazard, as the worlds most dangerous and tsunamigenic earthquakes occur on subduction zones for which the fault lies mostly, if not fully offshore. 

The project continued the development of large metal shields for protecting seismic sensors from currents from waves and from large scale currents. The shields  also protect the sensors from loss due to bottom trawling (fishing) which is common on most continental shelves. The project allowed us to assess the utility of the shields by comparing the noise on sensors mounted to the shield to sensors deployed isolated on the seafloor within the shield. The data showed the isolated sensors were as much as 30dB (more than a thousand times) quieter than the sensor mounted to the shield. 

The isolated sensor still showed noise relatable to ocean waves as the loading of ocean waves drives the seafloor vertically and horizontally. Previous work showed the vertical component of this noise could be mostly removed (by about 30dB) using observations of pressure gauges to measure the wave loading and then predicting the amount of ground motion expected due to the wave loading and subtracting this from the vertical component data. The noise levels on horizontal components of the seismometer are also very high as the wave loading tilts the seafloor and also drives horizontal motion. This noise should be proportional to the local horizontal gradients of pressure seen at the seafloor.  New, high sensitivity sensors were developed to measure seafloor pressure gradients in two orthogonal horizontal directions. Two deployments of the shield ocean bottom seismometer system with horizontal pressure gauges and a sensitive pressure gauge were conducted, one offshore of Northern California and the other south of Long Island in between 70 and 80m water depth. The data from these deployments demonstrated that much of the wave loading noise (about 20dB or a factor of about one hundred) could be predicted and removed from the horizontal component data greatly enhancing the potential utility of ocean bottom seismometer systems for seismology.   Future fleets of ocean bottom seismometer systems could employ these sensors to optimize the utility of the data obtained.
